channel.title: Challenge for you all

item.title: Challenge for you all
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“sh!ft, post:32, topic:136659”][quote author=frank_ link=topic=188190.msg1805205#msg1805205 date=1191697064]

One huge difference between our “hooks”, Ollie: my names aren’t totally misleading. Also, I disagree that the name “World” is wrong. A class containing the current “world” the player is on would be better named “ServerInfo”, to come up with a quick name.[quote author=Nerice link=topic=188190.msg1777815#msg1777815 date=1190639970]
Umm, do I have to use BCEL? Haven’t looked at the client in a year probably though so need some definitions to detect stuff. But using just a bytebuffer and offsets into it is sooooo much faster than BCEL. Offsets are set when the data is needed, or once it detects an unknown offset. Pretty much no offsets are set unless it needs or has to be, unless one is discovered while getting some other needed data.

Also since in the class file the method instruction bytecodes are unsigned instead of signed, it uses the unsigned byte so it don’t have to convert them either, stuff like that and other small things of course means less time.

Promise you, it would blow your times away… While your still loading classes, I would be setting hooks.
[/quote]Even though simplification is one of the biggest reasons for software? Sure, I could write a whole program in binary, but really, I have better things to do with my time.

Your the one talking about speed, and the more its left the way it is, the faster it is. Why create a new class if its not needed (automated processes dont need to be simplistic for a human to understand… the human should never be involved right?)? getString(index) will get the string as long as it leads to a string in the end (if its a class index, string index, or UTF8 index) and so forth, or getConstantClass(index) will return a actual class object that you are probably more accustomed to dealing with… but whats the use in that (other than more overhead?)?

It is rather simplistic to use… That is part of the objective when writing classes/libraries is it not? For someone not to have to understand or know how it works, just for it to be easy to use?

One thing you learn in college or at a university studying computer science is, it really doesn’t matter about its usability and functionality (not that those do not have value), it matters only that you get the job done.
[/quote]only if you have no standards, those of us whom have standards want something that not only works, but is easy to maintain and use

Clearly, you’ve never worked a day in your life… Or done anything but sit on your ass?[/quote]this, here, isnt the real world, you are writing something to use yourself

just because you are a dickhead, doesnt mean everyone else is

Read full topic

item.title: Challenge for you all
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

[quote=“sh!ft, post:30, topic:136659”][quote author=Nerice link=topic=188190.msg1802475#msg1802475 date=1191617980]

One huge difference between our “hooks”, Ollie: my names aren’t totally misleading. Also, I disagree that the name “World” is wrong. A class containing the current “world” the player is on would be better named “ServerInfo”, to come up with a quick name.[quote author=Nerice link=topic=188190.msg1777815#msg1777815 date=1190639970]
Umm, do I have to use BCEL? Haven’t looked at the client in a year probably though so need some definitions to detect stuff. But using just a bytebuffer and offsets into it is sooooo much faster than BCEL. Offsets are set when the data is needed, or once it detects an unknown offset. Pretty much no offsets are set unless it needs or has to be, unless one is discovered while getting some other needed data.

Also since in the class file the method instruction bytecodes are unsigned instead of signed, it uses the unsigned byte so it don’t have to convert them either, stuff like that and other small things of course means less time.

Promise you, it would blow your times away… While your still loading classes, I would be setting hooks.
[/quote]Even though simplification is one of the biggest reasons for software? Sure, I could write a whole program in binary, but really, I have better things to do with my time.

Your the one talking about speed, and the more its left the way it is, the faster it is. Why create a new class if its not needed (automated processes dont need to be simplistic for a human to understand… the human should never be involved right?)? getString(index) will get the string as long as it leads to a string in the end (if its a class index, string index, or UTF8 index) and so forth, or getConstantClass(index) will return a actual class object that you are probably more accustomed to dealing with… but whats the use in that (other than more overhead?)?

It is rather simplistic to use… That is part of the objective when writing classes/libraries is it not? For someone not to have to understand or know how it works, just for it to be easy to use?
[/quote]
One thing you learn in college or at a university studying computer science is, it really doesn’t matter about its usability and functionality (not that those do not have value), it matters only that you get the job done.[/quote]

Once you hit the real world and actually WORK dealing with code, you will find just getting the job done will be a fast way out the door, wether getting the job done works or not.

Read full topic

Why create a new class if its not needed (automated processes dont need to be simplistic for a human to understand… the human should never be involved right?)? getString(index) will get the string as long as it leads to a string in the end (if its a class index, string index, or UTF8 index) and so forth, or getConstantClass(index) will return a actual class object that you are probably more accustomed to dealing with… but whats the use in that (other than more overhead?)?

One thing you learn in college or at a university studying computer science is, it really doesn’t matter about its usability and functionality (not that those do not have value), it matters only that you get the job done.

item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

[quote=“Nerice, post:29, topic:136659”][quote author=Silver Lining link=topic=188190.msg1781152#msg1781152 date=1190784600]
One huge difference between our “hooks”, Ollie: my names aren’t totally misleading. Also, I disagree that the name “World” is wrong. A class containing the current “world” the player is on would be better named “ServerInfo”, to come up with a quick name.[quote author=Nerice link=topic=188190.msg1777815#msg1777815 date=1190639970]
Umm, do I have to use BCEL? Haven’t looked at the client in a year probably though so need some definitions to detect stuff. But using just a bytebuffer and offsets into it is sooooo much faster than BCEL. Offsets are set when the data is needed, or once it detects an unknown offset. Pretty much no offsets are set unless it needs or has to be, unless one is discovered while getting some other needed data.

Also since in the class file the method instruction bytecodes are unsigned instead of signed, it uses the unsigned byte so it don’t have to convert them either, stuff like that and other small things of course means less time.

Promise you, it would blow your times away… While your still loading classes, I would be setting hooks.
[/quote]Even though simplification is one of the biggest reasons for software? Sure, I could write a whole program in binary, but really, I have better things to do with my time.
[/quote]

Your the one talking about speed, and the more its left the way it is, the faster it is. Why create a new class if its not needed (automated processes dont need to be simplistic for a human to understand… the human should never be involved right?)? getString(index) will get the string as long as it leads to a string in the end (if its a class index, string index, or UTF8 index) and so forth, or getConstantClass(index) will return a actual class object that you are probably more accustomed to dealing with… but whats the use in that (other than more overhead?)?

It is rather simplistic to use… That is part of the objective when writing classes/libraries is it not? For someone not to have to understand or know how it works, just for it to be easy to use?[/quote]
One thing you learn in college or at a university studying computer science is, it really doesn’t matter about its usability and functionality (not that those do not have value), it matters only that you get the job done.

item.title: Challenge for you all
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

[quote=“Silver Lining, post:11, topic:136659”]One huge difference between our “hooks”, Ollie: my names aren’t totally misleading. Also, I disagree that the name “World” is wrong. A class containing the current “world” the player is on would be better named “ServerInfo”, to come up with a quick name.[quote author=Nerice link=topic=188190.msg1777815#msg1777815 date=1190639970]
Umm, do I have to use BCEL? Haven’t looked at the client in a year probably though so need some definitions to detect stuff. But using just a bytebuffer and offsets into it is sooooo much faster than BCEL. Offsets are set when the data is needed, or once it detects an unknown offset. Pretty much no offsets are set unless it needs or has to be, unless one is discovered while getting some other needed data.

Also since in the class file the method instruction bytecodes are unsigned instead of signed, it uses the unsigned byte so it don’t have to convert them either, stuff like that and other small things of course means less time.

Promise you, it would blow your times away… While your still loading classes, I would be setting hooks.
[/quote]Even though simplification is one of the biggest reasons for software? Sure, I could write a whole program in binary, but really, I have better things to do with my time.[/quote]

Your the one talking about speed, and the more its left the way it is, the faster it is. Why create a new class if its not needed (automated processes dont need to be simplistic for a human to understand… the human should never be involved right?)? getString(index) will get the string as long as it leads to a string in the end (if its a class index, string index, or UTF8 index) and so forth, or getConstantClass(index) will return a actual class object that you are probably more accustomed to dealing with… but whats the use in that (other than more overhead?)?

It is rather simplistic to use… That is part of the objective when writing classes/libraries is it not? For someone not to have to understand or know how it works, just for it to be easy to use?

item.title: Challenge for you all
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

[quote=“Silver Lining, post:26, topic:136659”][quote author=Ollie link=topic=188190.msg1793538#msg1793538 date=1191268837]that and also its possible for jagex to change the calculations, its not like i wouldn’t put it past them.
[/quote]No, it’s not. If you looked at what those arrays were, you might understand that.[/quote]
What happens if you multiplied everything by a factor (eg. 2) and then divided later?

It would probably slow things down but they already have heaps of crap in the client.

Read full topic

item.title: Challenge for you all
item.dc:creator: @sh_ft sh!ft
item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

They’re unit circle calculations, they can’t “change” them willy-nilly like Ollie and Silver Lining say, and computing them takes almost no time and is just as memory munching as hooking them when it’s not necessary.

Edit: Unit circle, you know, sin/cos…

Read full topic

item.title: Challenge for you all
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:19, topic:136659”][quote author=Silver Lining link=topic=188190.msg1792759#msg1792759 date=1191220022]
Why recalculate those values when they’ve already been done for you? Alternatively, you could just find said values when you need them, but still, it’s unnecessary.
[/quote]
that and also its possible for jagex to change the calculations, its not like i wouldn’t put it past them.[/quote]i have no idea what these camera curves are, but the only thing that resembles a curve are the sine and cosine of fractions of pi, is that what you are talking about? if so, they wont change

Read full topic

item.title: Challenge for you all
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:10, topic:136659”]its not that “hard”, he has just named things differently, like my “WorldController” is his “World”, which is a incorrect name, as there is already a “World” class which stores the current world the user is on.[/quote]Don’t get shitty, especially when you have no idea what you are talking about.

The World class as adopted by silver_lining is the world or universe for the game, the World class that you have so naively named is the identity of a server.

Read full topic

@Silver_Lining wrote:

One huge difference between our “hooks”, Ollie: my names aren’t totally misleading. Also, I disagree that the name “World” is wrong. A class containing the current “world” the player is on would be better named “ServerInfo”, to come up with a quick name.[quote=“Nerice, post:4, topic:136659”]Umm, do I have to use BCEL? Haven’t looked at the client in a year probably though so need some definitions to detect stuff. But using just a bytebuffer and offsets into it is sooooo much faster than BCEL. Offsets are set when the data is needed, or once it detects an unknown offset. Pretty much no offsets are set unless it needs or has to be, unless one is discovered while getting some other needed data.

Also since in the class file the method instruction bytecodes are unsigned instead of signed, it uses the unsigned byte so it don’t have to convert them either, stuff like that and other small things of course means less time.

Promise you, it would blow your times away… While your still loading classes, I would be setting hooks.[/quote]Even though simplification is one of the biggest reasons for software? Sure, I could write a whole program in binary, but really, I have better things to do with my time.

item.title: Challenge for you all
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

its not that “hard”, he has just named things differently, like my “WorldController” is his “World”, which is a incorrect name, as there is already a “World” class which stores the current world the user is on. but anywho we are not here to argue that,
i have most of these fields except

int getLowerTileVisibleX();
int getLowerTileVisibleY();
int getUpperTileVisibleX();
int getUpperTileVisibleY();

Read full topic
